question: How many regional meteorological offices does IMD have?
explanation:
Chennai Mumbai Kolkata Nagpur Guwahati New Delhi

subject: Meteorology

question: How many Aeronautical Meteorological Stations exist in India?
explanation:
Aeronautical Met Stations (AMS) (Total 54). These take Current Weather observations and provide aeronautical forecast after obtaining from AMOs, during their watch hours.

\n

 

\n
subject: Meteorology

question: Who issues SIGMETs?
explanation:
(j) SIGMET. It is the information issued for aircraft in flight by MWOs at Mumbai, Kolkata, New Delhi and Chennai, for their FIRs, for occurrence or expected occurrence of the following en-route weather which may affect safety of aircraft operations.It is issued every 3 hr, commencing 010 UTC. The validity of SIGMET is not more than 4 hr. For Volcanic Ash and Tropical Cyclones it is issued up to 12 hr before the period of validity and is updated every 6 hr. SIGMET are passed to FIC/ACC for further communication to aircraft in flight.

\n

 

\n
subject: Meteorology

question: What is the maximum validity period for airfield warnings?
explanation:
Warnings
. Aerodrome Warning.
These are issued by AMOs for expected weather which could adversely affect aircraft on ground and aerodrome facilities and services to ensure safety, proper picketing and mooring of aircraft :
The validity of these warnings is not exceeding 4hr.
Wind: Speed 30kt or more, or
Direction of 20 kt wind changes by 45 degrees.

Weather: Squall (also expected direction), TC, DS, SS, TS, GR, Frost, SN, Hoar Frost or Rime, FZ Precipitation, and Raising Sand or Dust, VA, Tsunami.
Warnings for gliders and light aircraft and helicopters are issued by AMOs, for own and AMSs, and appended to local forecast when wind speed is expected to reach 17 kt or more and are issued with the prefix Warnings for Light Aircraft.
subject: Meteorology

question: What is the validity period for landing forecasts (TREND)?
explanation:
TREND forecast is valid for 2 hours after the time of the observation of the METAR, and constitutes the final section of the METAR. The change in weather conditions indicated by the code, TREND, can be further qualified by the codes, BECMG, meaning becoming, or TEMPO meaning temporarily.

\n
subject: Meteorology

question: How frequently is the national SIGWX chart issued in India?
explanation:
four SIGWX forecasts of 24 hr validity based on 00, 06, 12 and18 UTC data. These are issued as :
High-level forecasts for levels between FL250 and FL630
Medium-level forecasts for levels between FL100 and FL250
subject: Meteorology

question: What does VOLMET consist of?
explanation:
VOLMET. It is a MET information for aircraft in flight. It is of two types:

Data Link VOLMET (D-VOLMET). It provides current METAR, SPECI, 9 hr TAF, SIGMET, Special AIREPS not covered by SIGMET, and where available AIRMET.

. VOLMET Broadcast. It provides METAR, SPECI, TAF, SIGMET by means of continuous and repetitive voice broadcasts. VOLMET Radio Telephony Broadcasts in India are made on HF Channel from Mumbai and Kolkata in turn every half an hour.
subject: Meteorology

subject: Meteorology

question: An airfield warning is issued when wind direction changes by how many knots from 20 kt?
explanation:
Warnings
. Aerodrome Warning.
These are issued by AMOs for expected weather which could adversely affect aircraft on ground and aerodrome facilities and services to ensure safety, proper picketing and mooring of aircraft :
The validity of these warnings is not exceeding 4hr.
Wind: Speed 30kt or more, or
Direction of 20 kt wind changes by 45 degrees.
Weather: Squall (also expected direction), TC, DS, SS, TS, GR, Frost, SN, Hoar Frost or Rime, FZ Precipitation, and Raising Sand or Dust, VA, Tsunami.
Warnings for gliders and light aircraft and helicopters are issued by AMOs, for own and AMSs, and appended to local forecast when wind speed is expected to reach 17 kt or more and are issued with the prefix Warnings for Light Aircraft.
The warnings are passed on to local ATS units for further dissemination over the aerodrome to the operators and others. These are not disseminated beyond the aerodrome of origin. Amendments and cancellations are done as applicable.

question: How large an area does a local forecast cover?
explanation:
Local/AreaForecast. Theseareissuedthree times a day, valid for 12 hr. They are issued at 0700 (valid 0730- 1930), 1300 (valid 1330- 0130), 1800 (valid 1830-0930) IST.

Area forecast covers 100 NM or more and

Local Forecast 50 NM around.

These contain forecast of surface wind, visibility, weather, clouds, upper winds and temperature, and information on sun rise, sunset, warning, etc.
subject: Meteorology

question: In an AIREP, in which section is the meteorological information included?
explanation:
Contents of Air Reports
Section 1 – Information on Identification, Position (Lat/Long), Time, FL or Altitude
Section 2 – Operational Information – ETA and Endurance.
Section 3 – Met Information – Air Temp ., Wind, TS, Turbulence, Icing and Humidity (if available)
Example : AIREP IA120 BHP 1200 UTC FL350 MS54 270/40KT TS SCT CB TOP FL 400=
subject: Meteorology

question: On which HF channel is the VOLMET radio broadcast made?
explanation:
VOLMET Broadcast. It provides METAR, SPECI, TAF, SIGMET by means of continuous and repetitive voice broadcasts. VOLMET Radio Telephony Broadcasts in India are made on HF Channel from Mumbai and Kolkata in turn every half an hour.

~ Mumbai Broadcasts include METARs of Mumbai, Ahmadabad, Chennai, Colombo, Karachi and Male and TAFs of Mumbai, Male and Colombo.

Kolkata Broadcasts include METAR s of Kolkata, Delhi, Dhaka, Yangon and Katmanduand TAFs of Kolkata, Delhi and Ho-Chi-Minh.
subject: Meteorology

question: Thunderstorms covering less than 50% of an area are termed what?
explanation:
ISOL TS : individual TS, less than 50% area covered;
OCNL TS- well separated TS, 50-75% area covered;
FRQ TS little or no separation between adjacent TS, > 75% area covered
subject: Meteorology

question: Thunderstorms covering 50–75% of an area with well-separated cells are called what?
explanation:
ISOL TS : individual TS, less than 50% area covered;
OCNL TS- well separated TS, 50-75% area covered;
FRQ TS little or no separation between adjacent TS, > 75% area covered

question: How many aerodrome meteorological offices are there?
explanation:
aerodrome met dep

Aerodrome Met Offices (AMO) (Total 18, including 4 MWOs). These are located at major National and International airports They maintain 24 h current weather watch, issue METAR/SPECI, RVR, weather forecasts, TAF, Landing Forecast, Aerodrome Warning, Briefing, VOLMET, ATIS, Radar and Satellite Pictures. They also provide forecasting cover to the associated Aeronautical Met Stations (AMS).
subject: Meteorology

question: Where is the landing forecast appended?
explanation:
A variation on the METAR is the Special Report. A Special Report, which is denoted by the abbreviation, SPECI, has the same format as a METAR except that the code SPECI will replace METAR at the beginning of the report. A SPECI will be issued when the weather conditions significantly change in the period between routine observations. A SPECI can be issued to indicate either an improvement or a deterioration in the weather.

question: How long are TAFs generally valid?
explanation:
Terminal Aerodrome Forecasts (TAFs) are forecasts of meteorological conditions at an aerodrome, as opposed to the report of actual, present conditions as given in a METAR.

TAFs usually cover a period of between 9 and 24 hours.

9-hour TAFs are issued every 3 hours, and 12 to 24-hour TAFS every 6 hours.
subject: Meteorology

question: When is a wind shear warning issued relative to a runway?
explanation:
The warnings are passed on to local ATS units for further dissemination over the aerodrome to the operators and others. These are not disseminated beyond the aerodrome of origin. Amendments and cancellations are done as applicable.
Wind Shear Warning (up to 500 m (1600 ft) above runway).
It is issued by AMOs for the observed or expected occurrence of wind shear which could adversely affect aircraft on approach path, take off path, during circling approach or on the RW during landing and take off. WS above 500m due to topography is also included.

question: In ROBEX, which data is exchanged for international aerodromes and alternates?
explanation:
ROBEX (Routine OPMET Bulletin Exchange). Routine METAR / SPECI of international aerodromes and their alternates are exchanged outside India under ROBEX scheme. Air Reports are also exchanged under ROBEX.

question: What type of forecasts does WAFS provide to meteorological offices?

choices.choice: high quality en-route forecasts of winds and temperature

explanation:
To meet pilots’ needs for meteorological information, in the early 1980s the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) developed the requirements for the World Area Forecast System (WAFS) to include the seamless forecasting of upper air winds, temperatures and significant weather hazards to enhance safety
